The Buyer's Journey

And how understanding it can help you increase sales

April 18, 2017

The Buyer's Journey is an incredibly useful concept to help better understand the motivation behind a consumer's purchases and how previous and future experiences will shape and affect decisions differently. It can be a useful tool to gather information from your customers and map out what their journey, and therefore their experience, is like on your site, and it provides a good reference point for improvements during various points of a sale.

What does the typical buyer journey look like?

There are three stages a buyer goes through when on their journey:

  1. Awareness Stage
  2. Consideration Stage
  3. Decision Stage

The Awareness Stage is when the consumer becomes aware of a problem that needs to be solved. This could be as simple as dishes need to be done, but they do not have any soap to wash the dishes, or more complex, like needing a computer that will be strong enough to handle professional applications and built well enough that it will be a long lasting computer for them to use.

The consumer then moves to the Consideration Stage, where they will then research, and gather as much information about products that can provide a solution to their problem as they can, in most cases. Depending on the scope of the product, this Stage will look different. There will obviously be much more thought and consideration put into the purchase of a computer, then for the purchase of dish soap. Various factors will be considered during this stage, such as:

  • Brand loyalty
  • Pricing
  • Prior experience
  • Sales
  • Popularity
  • Form and Function
  • Quality

After narrowing down their choices through research, the buyer comes to the end of their journey at the Decision Stage. At this stage, the buyer will make their final decision for a product to purchase, as well as go through post-purchase satisfaction or dissatisfaction. This is the stage where consumers also develop brand loyalty and wil determine if they will become a repeat buyer or not.

Consumer Conversion and Experience

The Consideration stage is one of the most important stages for marketers. This is the stage where all the efforts put behind a brand or product will come to fruition, and hopefully intrigue and influence the customer to convert. But it does not end there, the Decision Stage is equally important as this stage will cause a customer to avoid a product or brand or convert to a repeat buyer. User experience is imperative at this stage, particularly in the e-commerce realm.

If a customer has a bad experience, or finds it difficult to navigate a site or complete a purchase, they may decide to change their mind on what product they will buy, or swear off the brand or product for good. With markets getting increasingly over saturated, anything less then the absolute best possible experience will put you well behind the mark as far as your customers are concerned. You could have the price of a product beat by half, but if they struggle to purchase an item, cannot get a hold of a real person for questions, or are put off in any other way, they will go somewhere else.

A good tactic to track user experience is to create a roadmap to visualize the experience your customers are having. You can do this through prediction, putting yourself in the shoes of your buyer personas to try and emulate problems that specific targeted people may have, or through data collection of actual buyers and purchasers. Doing a combination of both will give you the highest advantage in regards to understanding your user experience, as well as establishing wins and opportunities.

The idea is that you track the exact steps a consumer has from the initial idea of purchasing your product until the receiving and using of your product and monitor for peaks and valleys. In the above example, a consumer is interested n a product, but cannot receive any social proof, so we experience the first valley, and then later has an issue with the product, which requires it to be repaired, but ultimately, in this case, the good outweighs the bad, and the consumer enjoys the product enough to recommend it.

By performing these audits with buyer personas and actual consumers, a company can track the good and bad and learn where to better focus their efforts with user experience. To learn more about buyer personas, you can read an article I wrote about them here. Making the map have as little valleys as possible is obviously ideal, and having input from multiple sources is the best way to determine if you are on the right track for having an all around easily accessible product. I challenge everyone to create a consumer journey map, and utilize it, and share in the comments what they have found. Identify your wins and opportunities and the changes you can make to turn those valleys into peaks on your maps for your customers.
